msIdentifier.msName: State Papers, Henry VIII: General Series

abstract.p: A letter from Nicholas Thorne, merchant of Bristol, to Thomas Cromwell, 1533.
The letter was also calendared in Letters and Papers, Henry VIII, VI, 1696.

div.p: Right worshipfull and my singular good maister /

Seing it hath pleasid you to take the payne to speke to my lorde Chauncellour
in my matier / That it will now please you to desier hym to see thend of my
said matier / My request is that I myght be at the same libertie as I was
at when I come to this Citie to sue the Executours to performe the legacies
in England / seing they had in their handes to do yt / and made aunswere
to these persones to whome the legacies were bequethed / that they fawted
to perfourme the legacies / which now is well approvid by the Accompte
that was made by the ?daismen and the Executor Executor / and brought before
my lorde Chauncellour / By the which it apperith the Executour hath
in his handes sufficient to performe all the said legacies in England with
more Cxlvij lili xiij s iiij d as remayneth of the same Accompte / Besides the
geyns and Advantage of certeyn Merchaundryes that he solde wt with more
certeyn erres presentid afore my lorde Chauncellour to be redressed /
The said Cxlvij li xiij s iiij d to be paide to me / And the Erres presentid
before my said lorde Chancellour to be redressed according to right and
conscyence / as he that desireth to see the will of his brother performyd
and to repair towardes my howse and to folow my pore trate and lyving
I will take at my charge and be bounde to see paide the legacies and almaner
of debtes in Spayne to pay all other maner of debtes knowyn as this
day and unkowyn / And to save the said ExecutorExecutor harmeles ayenst
almen for the legacies and debtes of the Testament / And more eny other
thing reasonable that may be thought by your mastership that I
ought to doo for the discharge of the saide Executour / So that in
like wise the said Executour wtoutewithoute delacon be bounde to Accomplissh
the legacies in England wt with spede seing that he hath redy money to do yt /
The greate busynes that you have had these dayes past hath causid
me not to resorte unto yor your maistership ( in Whome next to god ) is
myne onely trust of comforte / And yf in this it Were yor your pleasure
to be so good maister to help me to a quyet ende / I am and shalbe /
greatlye bound to prey for yor your maistership during my lyfe /

By yor your dayle oratour Nicholas
Thorne
